Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000479
Special Investigation Intake Date: March 17, 2025
License #: CI250410439
Licensee Group Organization: Prism Project
Licensee Designee: Sylvia Blythe
Chief Administrator: Sylvia Blythe
Agency Name: Mission Ranch
Agency Address: 9300 Lahring Road
Gaines, MI 48436
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 06/10/2025
Capacity: 6
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose

no findings

4/8/2025 12:32 PM Email Documentation received or sent

3/20/2025 10:30 AM Onsite Inspection Special Investigation Initiation

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A experienced an injury and infection to their foot and the
facility did not act on their need for medical attention promptly.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 04/10/2025
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth A
confirmed that she had been released back to the facility from the
hospital the day prior. Youth A detailed the course of events that
led to her foot being infected. It began as a result of an injury that
occurred when she jumped off of the balcony next to her bedroom
and fell approximately 10 feet to the ground. This occurred in
January 2025. Youth A reported several medical procedures and
setbacks that had occurred since and noted she had been
additionally in and out of psychiatric settings since the initial
injury. Youth A described coming back to the facility in mid-March
to resume her placement. She was using crutches, and her foot
was still healing. Youth A reported being provided prescribed pain
management medication and did not recall any concern with those
being provided to her as directed. Youth A voluntarily stopped
taking this medication because she didn’t feel like it was helping
her. She was prescribed a walking boot after the use of her
crutches ended, and she only used that boot for a few days before
discontinuing its use. Youth A recalled an appointment with an
orthopedic specialist where she was told her foot surgery had
progressed well, and the pins were taken out of her foot. Youth A
believed that an infection in her foot began at that time and was
later told by the orthopedic specialist that the pin pulling procedure
likely caused the infection. Youth A noticed a growth on the top of
her foot and then her skin bubbling up with fluid. She believed it
took about a week for her to be taken in to receive medical
attention for the possible infection. She believed she had told staff
about it and she felt like they were ignoring her. Youth A could not
provide any specific names other than Nurse 1 and Chief
Administrator in which she spoke about this. Youth A believed
she received help for medical concerns when she asked, but also
2

received a response with a negative attitude from staff. This
consisted of facial expressions such as smirking and times when
she believed she saw staff whispering to each other about
her. Youth A remarked that the foot infection has since
subsided. Youth A described the nursing services provided by the
facility, noting Nurse 1 and Chief Administrator normally act as
nursing staff on a day-to-day basis. She stated a doctor visits the
facility once per month to address the medical needs of the
youth. Youth A was not sure if this doctor had given attention to
her foot infection while it lasted.
Youth B was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 04/10/2025
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She was
asked about medical services provided at the facility. Youth B
described concern regarding an instance of a possible ear
infection. Youth B told Chief Administrator about the concern, as
well as the visiting doctor. Youth B reported over the counter
treatment was provided for her ear pain. Youth B recalled going
to the hospital at a later date and received treatment for her ear at
that time as well. Youth B stated being aware of Youth A’s foot
infection and the other complications that resulted from the broken
foot in January. Youth B expressed concern over the promptness
of medical treatment provided to Youth A but could not provide
further details.
Nurse 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 04/10/2025
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
described her role as an on-call nursing staff for the facility. She
often speaks with direct care staff regarding possible medical
needs for youth and sometimes speaks to the youth
themselves. Nurse 1 recalled participating in the ongoing
treatment of Youth A’s foot since it was broken in January. Nurse
1 recalled the specific timeframe when Youth A returned to the
facility from the hospital and then developed the infection in her
surgically repaired foot. At that time Youth A began to show
COVID related symptoms and was provided over-the-counter
treatment. Youth A was also picking at her surgical wound and
not keeping it regularly wrapped, and nursing staff were
attempting to have her stop doing so. As Youth A developed
more of a low-grade fever, Nurse 1 recalled seeing Youth A’s foot
show some swelling and clear drainage. She believed Youth A
had an upcoming medical appointment with the orthopedic
surgeon. Nurse 1 helped clean the wound. Nurse 1 did not
believe she had any other contact with Youth A after that date
because Youth A went to the hospital and only recently returned
to the placement. Nurse 1 did not believe there ever were times
3

she was contacted regarding a medical need for a youth and
attention was not provided to that need in a timely manner. Nurse
1 expressed concern youth at times would only be interested in
leaving the facility for medical attention when whatever was
occurring could be treated internally.
Chief Administrator was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on
04/10/2025 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the
facility. She provided a timeline of the time period in March when
concern raised of an infection of Youth A’s foot. Youth A’s foot
was assessed on 03/06/2025 by the facility doctor. On
03/07/2025 Chief Administrator recalled Youth A attending an
appointment with the orthopedic surgeon that had previously
pulled the pins from Youth A’s foot. An MRI was ordered at that
appointment. Chief Administrator confirmed Youth A had a home
visit with a prospective adoptive family from 03/07-03/09, and she
saw Youth A for her foot on 03/10. Chief Administrator recalled
Youth A’s foot looking worse at that time, and Nurse 1 provided
over-the-counter treatment for it. When Chief Administrator
witnessed Youth A’s foot not improving on 03/11, she called the
orthopedic professionals that had been treating Youth A for their
input, as well as sending pictures. She was informed that lab
work was ordered, and that the orthopedic office would attempt to
move up the previously scheduled MRI for Youth A. Chief
Administrator recalled seeing Youth A’s foot the following day and
believing it looked more inflamed and reported making multiple
calls to get more information on what course of action to
take. Youth A then proceeded to AWOL in the evening of
03/12/2025. Chief Administrator stated this was notable because
Youth A’s foot was showing signs of swelling, but Youth A also ran
on it a significant distance leaving and coming back to the
facility. Chief Administrator recalled ensuring Youth A soaked her
foot upon return from AWOL. She also remarked there was
consideration given to taking Youth A to the emergency room prior
to the AWOL on 03/12/2025, but ultimately that was not the
course of action taken because Youth A was moving on her foot
well, was not complaining of pain and other symptoms had not
gotten worse in the days prior. Chief Administrator expressed
concern that taking Youth A to the emergency room prior to
consultation with the orthopedic doctor would only cause the
emergency room services to be cut off until that consultation could
occur. She then stated receiving a call from the orthopedic office
the following morning on 03/13/2025. The doctor instructed Chief
Administrator to take Youth A to the emergency room for medical
treatment. Upon admittance to the hospital Youth A showed signs
of escalation and was eventually admitted for psychiatric
4

treatment while also receiving care for her foot. Chief
Administrator expressed never hearing youth state that their
medical concerns were not being addressed. She did not believe
Youth A had ever missed a medical appointment while at the
facility. She reported there were already follow up appointments
for Youth A’s foot scheduled since her return to the facility for
continued placement.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy regarding the medical treatment of youth
placed at the facility was provided and reviewed. This
stated that the facility would “ensure that emergency
medical treatment is available for residents in need.”
• Email documentation from the facility confirmed that Youth
A had a home visit and was away from the facility from 8:15
am on 03/07/2025 and returned to the facility at 8:40 pm on
03/09/2025.
o Youth A’s case file at the facility was provided and
reviewed. The following was reviewed:
o Facility Nursing Progress Note and documentation
from the Bay Pediatric Clinic stated Youth A was
seen by the facility doctor on 03/06/2025. Discussed
the orthopedic appointment that Youth A had
scheduled for the following day. Noted some
swelling and clear drainage to her foot.
o OrthoMichigan documentation showed that Youth A
had an appointment with the orthopedic specialist
the morning of 03/07/2025. X-rays were taken and a
Diagnostic Imagine Order Form additional MRIs
were ordered due to continued swelling of the foot.
o Home visit for Youth A from the morning of
03/07/2025 to the evening of 03/09/2025.
o Youth A was seen by the Chief Administrator on
03/10/2025 regarding her foot and multiple
seizures. On a Nursing Progress Note the Chief
Administrator noted seeing the foot as red and more
swollen. The documentation noted that the facility
nurse had scheduled an MRI for Youth A as
instructed by the orthopedic specialist.
o Youth A was seen by Nurse 1 on 03/11/2025. It was
noted on a Nursing Progress Note that the swelling
and redness had increased since the prior day. The
5

orthopedic specialist’s office was notified and stated
they would attempt to get the MRI appointment for
Youth A scheduled sooner for the facility.
o Youth A was seen by the Chief Administrator on
03/12/2025. Facility case notes documented that
the Chief Administrator called the orthopedic
specialist’s office again to receive a course of
direction for Youth A. It was documented that the
orthopedic specialist office called back the morning
of 03/13/2025 and advised taking Youth A to the
emergency room for labs and a CT scan of the foot.
o An After Visit Summary documented the admitting of
Youth A to the hospital to treat her foot on
03/13/2025.
o She was then released from the hospital to be
admitted to inpatient psychiatric placement on
03/18/2025.
o Incident report documentation from the facility was provided
and reviewed:
o On 01/09/2025 Youth A was upset and went out of
her bedroom to the connected balcony. This set off
an alarm and as staff reported to her room, Youth A
jumped off of her balcony to the brick patio
below. Youth A was taken to the hospital by
emergency medical services, was admitted and
scheduled for surgery.
o On 03/12/2025 there was an incident where Youth A
and another youth ran away from staff and AWOL’ed
while out on a walk near the facility. She was found
by law enforcement and brought back to the facility.
• Medical documentation for hospitalizations of Youth A was
provided and reviewed:
o An After Visit Summary dated 01/17/2025 described
the procedures performed after Youth A’s broken
foot, and follow up instructions including services
with the orthopedic specialist.
o An After Visit Summary dated 03/17/2025 described
the medical attention provided to Youth A’s foot
infection and provided follow up instructions
including further appointments with the same
orthopedic specialist.
• Further email communication between the Chief
Administrator and hospital staff where Youth A was
6

admitted after 03/13/2025 up to her placement back at the
facility was provided. This communication showed active
consultation between both parties about the treatment
needed for Youth A.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed Youth A was afforded
adequate health services during her placement at the facility.
Consultation
The facility was offered consultation on ways that youth can
provide written requests for medical attention from nursing staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
04/30/2025
_________________________________________________
Tyler Armstrong Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 30, 2025
